results.title: A Reason to read
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Studies the actions of students at three age levels- 5, 11 and 15 years and shows that in order to learn to read they must first want to read. It proposes that activities related to the teaching of reading should arise from the students own experience and interests, and that students should participate in the decision making concerning these activities. Features Croydon High, Enfield Junior and Gilles Street Primary schools.

results.title: The Puritan revolution: Cromwell and the rise of parliamentary democracy
results.creator_credit: Ken Hughes, Irving Allen, Columbia Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Shows how Parliament’s revolt, led by Cromwell and the puritans, erupts into full-scale civil war. When Charles is executed the absolute power of the monarchy ends and the nation is set on the road to parliamentary democracy. Specially edited from the film ‘Cromwell” starring Richard Harris as Cromwell and Alec Guiness as Charles I.

results.title: Pesticides: friend or foe?
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Bruce Moir and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows the need for great care in the preparation and use of pesticides. A home gardener and a farmer each make many mistakes when spraying. Shows the mistakes, the dangerous results and the correct procedures.

results.title: Paul Gauguin
results.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Films du Pantheon and Pictura Film Production
results.brief_description: Alain Resnais tells Gauguin’s story through his almost autobiographical paintings. At 35, Gauguin gave up a successful career in banking, deserted his wife and children and began to devote himself entirely to painting. The films commentary is drawn from direct translations of his letters, journals and other writings. Attracted to folk and primitive art, he sought to make his work simple, direct statements of highly personal emotions, rejecting the scientific theories of impressionism and all the notions of a purely representational art. The film’s commentary is drawn from direct translations of his letters, journals and other writings.

results.title: Paris la nuit
results.creator_credit: Jacques Baratier, Jean Valere, Argos Films and Como Films
results.brief_description: An impressionistic approach to documentary film production utilising a variety of striking images which at times suggest an almost surrealistic sense of humour. Jacques Baratier and Jean Valere have captured Paris nightlife in 1956 featuring its streets and inhabitants, cabarets, Chansonniers and other entertainments, its lights and edifices. As the night progresses, Parisians return to their homes and venues close as markets prepare to open. Excellent cinematography by Maurice Barry. A film without dialogue, incorporating songs in its soundtrack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques Baratier, Jean Valere, Argos Films and Como Films

results.title: Parent teacher interviews
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, John Morris, South Australia. Dept. of Education and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Five encounters which typify the difficulties in communication that often arise in parent-teacher interviews. 1. The Major by Yvonne Graves. Teacher: Brian Victory. Parents: Julie Dawson, Leslie Dayman. - 2. Doctor Lawyer Indian Chief by Brian Bergin. Teacher: Julie Hamilton. Parents: Di Chamerlain, Alan Becher. - 3. A Stranger by Brian Bergin. Teacher: Paul Weingott. Parents: Carol Skinner, Ian Gray. - 4. A Matter of Motivation by Yvonne Graves. Teacher: Colin Myers. Parents: Christine Martin-Murphy, Patrick Frost. - 5. Dear Miss Stevens by Yvonne Graves. Teacher: Noni Hazelhurst. Mother: Mary Taylor.

results.title: Oxidation and reduction
results.creator_credit: Herman J. Engel, Max J Rosenberg and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the relationship and the differences between oxidation and reduction. Explains this type of reaction in terms of electron transfer. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Outward bound
results.creator_credit: Barry Corbet, Joern Gerdts, Robert Fulton, Roger C. Brown, Crystal Productions and Summit Films
results.brief_description: The benefits of the outward bound course, including increased autonomy and knowledge of people, and the psychological kick to be had from danger. Good photography and much use of music. This is not an instructional film.
